questions.text: Which of the following is the primary vector for transmitting the plague to humans?
Which flea indices are considered the most significant for predicting plague outbreaks?
Which of the following is considered the most effective method to break the transmission cycle of plague?

A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 20 weeks of gestation visits a PHC for her antenatal check-up. Her last tetanus vaccination was 12 years ago. According to the National Immunization Schedule of India, what is the most appropriate tetanus vaccination recommendation for this patient ?

options.label: A
options.text: No vaccination is required as she received a TT dose 12 years ago

options.label: B
options.text: Administer one dose of Td vaccine immediately

options.label: C
options.text: Administer two doses of Td vaccine, 4 weeks apart

options.label: D
options.text: Administer three doses of TT vaccine at 0, 1, and 6 months

questions.correct_answer: C. Administer two doses of Td vaccine, 4 weeks apart
questions.explanation:
Vaccine

When to give

Dose

Route

Site

Td-1

Early in pregnancy

0.5 ml

Intramuscular

Upper Arm

Td-2

4 weeks after Td-1

0.5 ml

Intramuscular

Upper Arm

Td- Booster

If received 2 Td doses in a pregnancy within the last 3 yrs

0.5 ml

Intramuscular

Upper Arm

questions.text: What is the most effective and efficient measure for preventing neonatal tetanus during delivery?

options.label: A
options.text: Administering tetanus toxoid vaccine to the mother during pregnancy

options.label: B
options.text: Ensuring clean delivery practices, including the use of sterile instruments

options.label: C
options.text: Providing antibiotics to the newborn immediately after birth

options.label: D
options.text: Applying an antiseptic solution to the umbilical cord stump

questions.correct_answer: B. Ensuring clean delivery practices, including the use of sterile instruments

questions.text: A 35-year-old construction worker sustained a deep puncture wound on his foot while working at a site. He stepped on a rusty nail. He was immediately taken to the nearest clinic. He does not recall his last tetanus vaccination. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate action to prevent tetanus in this patient ?

options.label: A
options.text: Clean the wound with soap and water and administer the tetanus toxoid (TT) vaccine.

options.label: B
options.text: Clean the wound thoroughly, administer tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG), and give a tetanus toxoid (TT) booster.

options.label: C
options.text: Administer a course of antibiotics and advise him to keep the wound clean.

options.label: D
options.text: Clean the wound thoroughly, provide a tetanus toxoid (TT) booster

questions.correct_answer: B. Clean the wound thoroughly, administer tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG), and give a tetanus toxoid (TT) booster.
questions.explanation:
Category

Clean wound

Unclean wound

Category A

Has had a complete course of toxoid or a booster dose (full immunization) within the past 5 years.

Only wound care.

Only wound care. (Option C)

Category B

Full immunization > 5 years ago    < 10 years.

Wound Care + TT single dose.

Wound Care + TT single dose. (Option A)

Category C

Full Immunization > 10 years ago.

Wound Care + TT single dose.

Wound Care + TT single dose + Human Tetanus Immunoglobulin.

Category D

Unknown, not known, never taken immunization.

Wound Care + TT complete

course.

Wound Care + TT complete course + Human Tetanus Immunoglobulin.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman visits the health clinic for a routine check-up. During the consultation, she mentioned her concern about HIV infection, as she recently learned that a close friend was diagnosed with HIV. She wants to understand the most efficient and most common routes of HIV transmission to protect herself better. Which of the following methods is the most efficient route of HIV transmission?
questions.explanation:
Route of Transmission

Prevalence

Efficiency of the Route

Sexual route

87 - 90% of the cases

0.01 - 1%

Blood Transfusion

<1% of the cases

>95%

Sharing needles and syringes

1% of the total cases

5-10%

Needle prick injury

<1% cases

0.3%

Mother-to-child transmission

5% of the total cases

25 -30%

30% for developing countries

questions.text: Which of the following diseases cannot be prevented by both active and passive immunization?
Which of the following is not considered a high-risk group for HIV infection?

options.label: B
options.text: Men who have sex with men (MSM)

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the clinic with a fever, sore throat, rash, and generalised lymphadenopathy. He mentions that he has multiple sexual partners, and he uses condoms inconsistently. Based on the scenario, in which clinical stage of HIV infection is this patient most likely?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Features

Initial Infection
  • Occurs after initial infection with HIV.
  • Mild symptoms: fever, sore throat, rash, and generalized lymphadenopathy (infectious mononucleosis-like illness); May remain asymptomatic.
  • Antibodies appear within 2-12 weeks of infection.

Asymptomatic carrier state

No obvious signs of illness except for persistent generalized lymphadenopathy.(Option A)

AIDS-Related Complex (ARC)
  • Symptoms: prolonged diarrhea, fatigue, significant weight loss (>10% body weight).
  • Mild opportunistic infections like oral thrush can occur.
  • The number of T-helper lymphocytes decreases but does not meet the criteria for AIDS. (Option C)

Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS)
  • Advanced stage of HIV infection - severe immune deficiency
  • Opportunistic infections can occur(AIDS defining illnesses can occur) (Option D)
    • Tuberculosis
    • Kaposi's sarcoma
    • Fungal infections (e.g. Candida, Cryptococcus, Pneumocystis pneumonia)
    • Parasitic infections (e.g. Toxoplasma encephalitis)
  • They can also develop wasting syndrome, chronic diarrhea, and AIDS dementia.

✔

questions.text: A public health team is investigating an outbreak of a viral hemorrhagic fever in a remote village. Several villagers are experiencing severe symptoms, including fever, vomiting, diarrhoea, and unexplained bleeding. The investigation reveals that the initial patients had contact with wild animals in the nearby forest. What is the primary natural reservoir for this virus in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ebola virus

Nipah virus

Natural reservoir

Bats

Bats

Bats → Pigs → Humans

Modes of transmission

  • Bat bites
  • Body secretion (blood, urine, faeces, seminal fluid)
  • Sexual route
  • Direct contact with infected animals
  • Body secretion (blood, urine, faeces, seminal fluid)
  • Consumption of contaminated food products (palm sap or fruits)

Incubation period

2 to 21 days

4-14 days

Clinical features

Fever, chills, myalgia, diarrhea, bleeding, and multi-organ failure (case fatality rate- 50 to 90%)

Fever, chills, headache

Encephalitis, acute respiratory distress syndrome

Multiorgan failure, GIT hemorrhage (case fatality rate- 40-70%)

questions.text: All of the following pathogens are category A bioterrorism agents, except?
questions.explanation:
Category A

Category B

Category C

Priority

High-priority agents posing a risk to national security

Second highest priority

Third highest priority with emerging pathogens

The reason they are classified into the respective categories:
  • Easily disseminated in the environment
  • High mortality risk
  • Cause public panic and social disruption
  • Requires special action for public health preparedness
  • Moderately easy to disseminate.
  • Moderate morbidity risk.
  • Requires enhanced disease surveillance.
  • It can be engineered for mass dissemination in the future.
  • It has the potential for high mortality and morbidity.

Examples:
  • Bacillus anthracis - Anthrax (Option B)
  • Francisella tularensis - Tularemia (Option D)
  • Clostridium botulinum - Botulism
  • Yersinia pestis - Bubonic plague
  • Ebola virus - Ebola hemorrhagic fever (Option A)
  • Clostridium perfringens - epsilon toxin
  • Cryptosporidium parvum
  • Escherichia coli (O157:H7)
  • Shigella dysenteriae
  • Salmonella
  • Vibrio cholera
  • Hantavirus
  • MDR-tuberculosis
  • Nipah Virus
  • Yellow fever
  • Tick-borne encephalitis /hemorrhagic fever

questions.text: A 35-year-old man from a rural area in Kerala visits the clinic with symptoms of fever, headache, dizziness, and respiratory problems. He mentions that he has also been experiencing muscle pain and nausea for the past few days. On examination, the patient exhibits signs of encephalitis. Based on the scenario, what is the likely incubation period for this viral infection?
questions.explanation:
Disease

Incubation Period

Ebola virus

2-21 days (Option B)

Zika virus

2-7 days (Option A)

Nipah

4-14 days (Option D)

Scrub Typhus

10-12 days (Option C)

questions.text: A public health officer is investigating an outbreak of a viral illness in a tropical region. The affected individuals present with symptoms such as fever, maculopapular skin rash, conjunctivitis, and joint pain. The officer needs to identify the primary vector responsible for the transmission of the virus to implement effective control measures. Which vector is primarily responsible for transmitting the virus?
